moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 Bf5 3. e3 e6: the symmetrical approach, for 1. d4: White forfeits the Queens' gambit with 2. c4, in favor of an English style opening; the Mason variation...
moves.4. c3 Bd6 5. Bg3 Nf6 6. Bd3 Bxd3 7. Qxd3: not exactly, what White was hoping for: Black is already better...
moves.15... dxc4 16. Ndxc4 Qd5 17. Rad1 Rfd8 1: underestimating Blacks' possibilities: Qe2 is safer, leaving Ne3 open after an upcoming b5...
moves.19... Nxe5 20. Qxe5: forced: after dxe5, Qxd1, suddenly all is over...
moves.23. Rd2 Rd7 24. Rc2: hard, to find a better move: this however, will cost a very important pawn...
not good: better a3, e5, Nb3, or even f3, Kd6, a3, e5, Nb3...
moves.30. a3 Na2 31. Rxa2 Rc4xc1+ 32. Nxc1 Rxc: better try Ra7+, Ke6, Ra6+, Kf5, Ra7, Kg6, Re7...
moves.44... Kxb4 45. Rc8: in vain: White is too late, to save anything...
no way back: Black is winning...
moves.49. Kg1 Rc5 50. Ra8 Kc4: ending all illusions for White: the b-pawn will promote; so White resigned...
